unnormalised: India's fuel consumption is a hot topic, especially with prices fluctuating more than my mood after a bad cup of chai! We’re all feeling the pinch at the petrol pump, right? I mean, who isn’t checking the fuel gauge like 10 times on the way to work? It's not just petrol, though. Diesel, CNG – everything’s going up. Even that scooter ride to the nearby market feels expensive now.

unnormalised: Let’s talk numbers for a sec. Last month, my car guzzled about 50 litres of petrol, costing me a small fortune. And it's not just cars; consider the trucks carrying goods across the country. Each of those monsters probably burns through 200+ litres on a single trip from Delhi to Mumbai. That’s a whole lotta fuel! Imagine the costs for those businesses and how it eventually reflects in the prices of everyday stuff.

unnormalised: The price per litre varies a lot depending on where you are. In Mumbai, you might be paying ₹105, while in Delhi, it could be ₹96. And don't even get me started on the taxes! A huge chunk of what we pay goes straight to the govt. It’s all a bit much, isn’t it? I wish someone figured out how to make our cars run on chai instead of petrol.

unnormalised: Alternatives, you say? Electric vehicles (EVs) are definitely gaining traction. My neighbour, Mr. Sharma, just bought an EV scooter. He says it only costs him about Rs. 50 for a full charge, and it lasts him for about 80 km. That's way cheaper than my petrol bill! More and more people are considering EVs now with all the subsidies going around.

unnormalised: Then there's CNG (Compressed Natural Gas). Many auto-rickshaws and taxis in cities like Delhi run on CNG. It’s considered a cleaner fuel, and it's generally cheaper than petrol or diesel. You can probably run an auto for a whole day using just 10 kg of CNG, which is pretty efficient. So, that’s a step in the right direction.

unnormalised: Ultimately, India’s fuel story is one big balancing act – prices, consumption, pollution, and the search for alternatives. We're all trying to save every drop and km to keep our pockets from emptying, or at least, empting slower. Maybe someday, we’ll all be zipping around in chai-powered vehicles. Fingers crossed!
